Article Title: Former OpenAI researcher’s mother breaks silence on his death; says ‘It doesn’t look like a normal…’
Article Text:
OpenAI issues statement

Suchir Balaji , a 26-year-old Indian-origin former OpenAI employee, was discovered dead in his Buchanan Street apartment on Thanksgiving Day last week. The San Francisco Medical Examiner’s Office ruled the death as suicide, with no signs of foul play. Days after, his mother Poornima Ramarao has opened up about her son’s death. In an interview with Business Insider, his mother revealed that Balaji had grown increasingly disillusioned with artificial intelligence (AI), particularly OpenAI’s shift toward commercialization with ChatGPT .Poornima Ramarao said, “He felt AI is a harm to humanity,” describing how her son, Suchir Balaji, transitioned from boundless optimism about AI’s potential to profound skepticism. Reflecting on his tragic death, she added, “It doesn’t look like a normal situation.”Suchir Balaji worked at OpenAI for nearly four years before resigning in August this year. One of his early contributions, a project called WebGPT , is credited with laying the groundwork for ChatGPT.Balaji had openly voiced concerns about potential copyright violations by OpenAI and other AI firms, particularly the use of copyrighted material to train generative AI models like ChatGPT. These concerns drew attention amid a growing wave of lawsuits from writers, programmers, and journalists accusing AI companies of unauthorized use of their work.Expressing its condolences following the passing of the former researcher, OpenAI has released a statement on Thursday, December 26. The company confirmed its support for Balaji's family during this challenging time. The statement, shared on OpenAI's newsroom, marks exactly one month since Balaji's death on November 26.“We were devastated to learn of this tragic news and have been in touch with Suchir's family to offer our full support,” the statement read. “Our priority is to continue to do everything we can to assist them.”
Article Summary: Suchir Balaji, a 26-year-old Indian-origin former OpenAI employee, was discovered dead in his Buchanan Street apartment on Thanksgiving Day last week. The San Francisco Medical Examiner’s Office ruled the death as suicide, with no signs of foul play. In an interview with Business Insider, his mother revealed that Balaji had grown increasingly disillusioned with artificial intelligence.

Article Title: Google Drive’s latest update improves video-watching experience, here’s how
Article Text:
Watching uploaded videos instantly on Google Drove: How is it important



Google Drive now allows users to stream videos immediately after they are uploaded. This update marks the latest in a series of enhancements to the platform's video playback capabilities. This new feature eliminates the wait time previously required for processing before viewing. This improvement follows a major overhaul of Drive's video player in October, which introduced a refreshed user interface and new playback controls.These video-focused upgrades are part of a broader effort by Google to enhance Drive's functionality. Last week, the company introduced an improved document scanner to the cloud storage platform. In 2024, Google added multiple new features to its cloud storage service, making it more than just a basic storage solution. Google Drive now boasts a range of functionalities, including automated backup tools and advanced sharing options.The importance of Google Drive's new instant video playback feature lies in how it addresses the platform's video processing. While Drive preserves the original uploaded video file for download, it also creates a stream-optimised version for its built-in player, similar to YouTube's transcoding process.However, this transcoding can take considerable time. Now, users can start watching their videos immediately after uploading, even though sharing through the Drive player still requires processing to complete. This is a notable improvement for users who frequently work with video files, as it allows for quicker identification and access to content within uploaded clips.
Article Summary: Google Drive now allows users to stream videos immediately after they are uploaded. This new feature eliminates the wait time previously required for processing before viewing. It follows a major overhaul of Drive's video player in October, which introduced a refreshed user interface and new playback controls.

Article Title: NPCI issues an advisory about 'online scams' that Indians are losing crores to
Article Text:
What NPCI advisory says

What is digital arrest scam



How to identify a digital arrest scam

Unexpected Contact from ‘Officials’: Be cautious if someone claims to be from government agencies like the police, CBI, income tax officers, or customs agents, contacts you. Be cautious especially if they claim urgent legal action is being initiated or warranted. They might allege that you or one of your family members is involved in a serious crime like money laundering, tax evasion, or drug trafficking.

Fear-based language and urgency: Scammers may request video calls, disguising themselves in police uniforms, using government logos, or creating official-sounding background noise to appear legitimate. They often threaten arrest or immediate legal action, demanding a quick response and using legal terms to sound convincing. In some cases, they create a police station-like set up to further convince victims of their credibility.

Request for sensitive information or payment: Scammers may ask for personal information or demand large sums of money, promising that this will clear up your involvement in the alleged crime. They may also coerce you to transfer money to their account until the investigation is complete. Terms like “clearing your name”, “assisting with the investigation”, or “refundable security deposit/escrow account” might be used by them to persuade you into transferring money to specified bank accounts or UPI IDs.

Tips to stay safe

Pause and Verify: If you receive unexpected calls or messages about legal issues, take a moment to verify. Stay calm, as scammers rely on fear and urgency. Real government and law enforcement agencies will never ask for money or investigate cases through phone or video calls. Always confirm the caller’s identity and consult trusted sources before taking any action.

Use Support Channels: Report suspicious numbers to the national cybercrime helpline by dialing 1930 or the Department of Telecommunication (https://sancharsaathi.gov.in/sfc/).

Article Title: Airbnb blocked 74,000 bookings worldwide on New Year eve in 2023, and says will follow same measures in 2024 as well
Article Text:
How Airbnb checks ‘party’ booking

Planning a New Year's Eve party at an Airbnb? Think again. The company is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. This technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location. While implemented worldwide, the technology will specifically target the US, UK, Australia, Canada, France, Puerto Rico, Spain and New Zealand. Last New Year's Eve, Airbnb blocked 74,000 such bookings.High-risk bookings will be blocked or redirected to alternative accommodations. Short holiday getaways (one to three nights) in entire homes will also be restricted, and guests booking entire homes will be required to agree to a "mandatory anti-party attestation." "If a booking is identified as higher risk, the guest will either be blocked from booking, or redirected to alternative accommodations on the platform," the company said.Guests will also be required to accept mandatory anti-party attestation. "Guests who can make reservations will need to confirm that they understand that disruptive and unauthorized parties are not allowed on Airbnb, and they face suspension or removal from the platform if they violate this policy," said the company.Airbnb also has a 'Neighborhood Support Line' for local communities to report urgent issues, like a party in progress, at a home they believe is listed on Airbnb.Airbnb's efforts to curb disruptive parties started in 2019 with a ban on "party houses," followed by stricter measures in 2020 due to the pandemic. In 2022, the company permanently banned large parties worldwide following several violent incidents at Airbnb rentals, including a shooting in Pittsburgh that resulted in two deaths and eight injuries.
Article Summary: Airbnb is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. The technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location.

Article Title: Who is the group that US and Japan have blamed for the $300 million crypto theft
Article Text:
Japan and US hold North Korea responsible for $300 million crypto theft



Involvement of Lazarus Group and North Korea’s cyber operations



The role of cryptocurrency in North Korea's financial strategy

The global impact and ongoing investigations

North Korea’s cyber warfare: A growing threat

Also read |

|

|

In a significant cybersecurity breach, a North Korean hacking group has stolen over $300 million worth of cryptocurrency from DMM Bitcoin, a Japan-based exchange, according to reports from Japanese police and the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). The theft, which occurred in late May 2024, highlights the growing threat of cybercrime linked to North Korea 's extensive and well-established hacking operations. The incident underscores the increasing use of cryptocurrency theft as a method of generating illicit revenue, with global implications for both the cryptocurrency industry and international cybersecurity efforts. The cyberattack, attributed to the "TraderTraitor" group, is believed to be a part of the infamous Lazarus Group, which has a history of cyberattacks tied to North Korea's government. The FBI and Japanese authorities are working in tandem to investigate the breach and prevent future attacks.The DMM Bitcoin breach was carried out through a highly sophisticated social engineering scheme that allowed North Korean cyber actors to infiltrate the exchange's systems. According to the FBI's report, the attackers targeted an employee of a different cryptocurrency wallet software company through LinkedIn. Posing as a recruiter, the hacker initiated contact with the employee and sent them what appeared to be a pre-employment test. However, the test was a cleverly disguised phishing attempt that contained malicious code. When the employee unknowingly executed the file, it granted the hacker access to their system.This seemingly minor breach gave the attacker the opportunity to impersonate the employee and manipulate legitimate transactions within DMM Bitcoin’s infrastructure. By May 2024, the hacker was able to exploit this access to authorize the transfer of 4,502.9 Bitcoin, a sum worth $308 million at the time of the theft. The cryptocurrency was subsequently moved to an external wallet controlled by the perpetrators. This method of attack, leveraging human error and exploiting trust in digital communications, is a stark reminder of the vulnerabilities in the cybersecurity landscape, particularly when employees are targeted as the entry point.The TraderTraitor group, responsible for the heist, is believed to be part of Lazarus Group, a notorious hacking collective linked to North Korea's government. Lazarus gained global attention in 2014 after it was accused of orchestrating a cyberattack on Sony Pictures in retaliation for the release of The Interview, a satirical film that mocked North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Since then, Lazarus has been implicated in a series of high-profile cyberattacks, including the 2017 WannaCry ransomware attack, which affected organizations worldwide.The FBI's detailed analysis and investigation into the DMM Bitcoin incident confirm the link between TraderTraitor and Lazarus, further cementing the group’s role in North Korea’s broader cyber warfare strategy. Lazarus has been accused of using cybercrime as a means to generate revenue for the North Korean regime, bypassing international sanctions and supporting the country's economy in the face of increasing global isolation.North Korea’s cyber warfare program, which traces its origins to the mid-1990s, has evolved into a formidable force. According to a 2020 U.S. military report, the country now operates a highly specialized unit known as Bureau 121. This unit is reportedly made up of 6,000 cyber operatives working from various countries to carry out a range of cyber operations, including espionage, sabotage, and financial theft.Cryptocurrency has increasingly become a central element of North Korea’s financial strategy. With international sanctions severely limiting the country’s access to the global financial system, North Korean cybercriminals have turned to digital currencies as a way to generate illicit revenue. Cryptocurrencies, with their decentralized and pseudonymous nature, present an attractive target for cybercriminals, offering a way to bypass traditional banking systems and launder stolen funds more effectively.The theft from DMM Bitcoin is just one example of how North Korea has leveraged cryptocurrency for its own financial gains. In addition to direct thefts like the one at DMM, the regime has been linked to a variety of other cyber activities aimed at accumulating digital currencies. These activities include hacking cryptocurrency exchanges, stealing wallets, and exploiting vulnerabilities in blockchain technologies. The proceeds from these operations are believed to fund the country’s weapons programs, military expenditures, and the regime’s continued defiance of international sanctions.The DMM Bitcoin breach has broader implications for the global cryptocurrency industry, which is still grappling with how to secure its infrastructure against sophisticated attacks. Cryptocurrency exchanges, digital wallets, and blockchain technology companies are increasingly becoming targets of cyberattacks, and incidents like the one involving DMM Bitcoin highlight the need for enhanced cybersecurity measures.In response to the theft, the FBI, Japan’s National Police Agency, and other international law enforcement agencies have launched joint efforts to track down those responsible and prevent similar incidents in the future. As part of this effort, authorities are focusing on uncovering the tactics used by North Korean hackers and improving the resilience of the cryptocurrency sector against cyber threats.The DMM Bitcoin theft also brings attention to the role of international cooperation in combating cybercrime. As cryptocurrency transactions often transcend national borders, it is essential for governments and law enforcement agencies to collaborate closely in addressing the global nature of these crimes.North Korea's cyber activities are not limited to cryptocurrency thefts. The regime has consistently used cyber tools for a wide range of operations, including espionage, disruption of critical infrastructure, and attacks on foreign businesses and governments. Bureau 121, which is believed to be behind many of these attacks, represents one of the largest and most advanced state-sponsored cyber programs in the world.The capabilities of North Korean hackers continue to evolve, and the country's cyber operations are expected to remain a significant threat to global cybersecurity for the foreseeable future. As the use of cyber warfare becomes more prevalent in international conflicts, nations and organizations worldwide will need to adapt their defenses to address this growing risk.
Article Summary: A North Korean hacking group has stolen over $300 million worth of cryptocurrency from DMM Bitcoin, a Japan-based exchange. The theft, which occurred in late May 2024, highlights the growing threat of cybercrime linked to North Korea's extensive and well-established hacking operations. The FBI and Japanese authorities are working in tandem to investigate the breach and prevent future attacks.

Article Title: How iPhone’s biggest supplier aims to reduce dependency on China
Article Text:
What Foxconn said about its global expansion



Difficulties that Foxconn may face



Taiwanese tech giant Foxconn is diversifying its manufacturing operations globally to lessen its reliance on China. The company which is also the biggest global supplier of Apple’s iPhones expects potential tariffs from the US on Chinese imports amid rising trade tensions . The company has spent millions of dollars over the past two years expanding its operations worldwide. This includes a recent $33 million purchase of a 10-acre tract north of Houston for expansion, as well as investments in new factories in India and Mexico and further commitments in Thailand, reports the New York Times (NYT).These moves come as US President-elect Donald Trump has pledged to impose tariffs on goods imported from China, among other countries, upon taking office next month. Foxconn, a major producer of consumer electronics, is reportedly preparing for such a scenario for several years.Foxconn's chairman, Young Liu, recently explained that the company's strategic expansion worldwide is designed to mitigate the impact of expected tariffs. During a forum in Taipei, Liu told reporters, "The impact on us is likely smaller compared to our competitors," after the company closed its Texas deal. The company’s newly acquired Texas land, located adjacent to one of its existing warehouses, is slated for development related to the company's AI operations .Apart from this, Foxconn's global expansion includes hundreds of millions of dollars invested in land and equipment for new factories. These include facilities in India's Karnataka and Tamil Nadu for iPhone production and in Mexico's Jalisco for AI server manufacturing. Additionally, a Foxconn subsidiary received approval from Thailand's government for a $300 million investment in its computer chip component business, earlier this month.Foxconn's global expansion reflects a broader trend among multinational companies, especially in Asia, to diversify supply chains and shift manufacturing away from China. This restructuring was spurred by the trade war initiated during the previous administration and is further driven by the prospect of new tariffs.While companies hope this diversification will lessen the impact of potential upcoming tariffs, replicating the manufacturing ecosystem that benefited from years of government-backed infrastructure investment in China will be challenging, the NYT report claims.Despite previous investments in smaller factories abroad, none have matched the scale or revenue generation of Foxconn's Chinese operations. However, last year, Foxconn's chairman vowed to change that.3
Article Summary: Taiwanese tech giant Foxconn is diversifying its manufacturing operations globally to lessen its reliance on China. The company has spent millions of dollars over the past two years expanding its operations worldwide. Foxconn's chairman, Young Liu, recently explained that the company's strategic expansion worldwide is designed to mitigate the impact of expected tariffs.

Her call for a more realistic approach resonates with growing concerns about the long-term viability of many startups, particularly those reliant on unsustainable funding models.

Despite having 14 other job offers from established companies during the dot-com boom, Mayer chose the then-unknown startup after recalling her Stanford professor Eric Roberts' suggestion to meet founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin The decision aligned with Mayer's pattern of embracing uncertainty in her career choices. This philosophy, combined with her practice of surrounding herself with brilliant minds, influenced her choice to join the fledgling search engine company.Mayer's 13-year tenure at Google preceded her appointment as Yahoo's CEO, where she led the company through significant changes, including tripling its stock price and orchestrating its $4.48 billion sale to Verizon in 2017.Currently, Mayer serves on the boards of prominent companies including Walmart , AT&T, and Nextdoor Holdings. Amazon denies

Chinese sellers are reportedly caught in the middle as Amazon battles to maintain its dominance in the U.S. ecommerce market. According to the South China Post, Amazon has instructed some Chinese cross-border merchants to stop listing goods at lower prices on the rival platform, Temu . The report states that Amazon's local office recently notified managers of top-selling Chinese brands, advising them not to list identical items at reduced prices on Temu.Adding fuel to the fire, Anker, a popular brand on Amazon, recently removed its listings from Temu's US marketplace. This move fueled speculation that Amazon pressured Anker to prioritize its platform. However, Temu maintains its commitment to "fair and open competition" and said that it believes offering products across platforms benefits consumers with more choices and better deals.Temu is owned by Chinese e-commerce giant PDD Holdings . The ecommerce website has gained popularity rapidly since its launch in the year 2022. Its aggressive pricing strategy is said to be attracting US consumers and threatening Amazon's market share. Temu was the world’s third-most-visited online marketplace after Amazon and Alibaba Group Holding’s AliExpress, according to November data from Similarweb.Sellers who violate this rule risk losing their placement in Amazon's coveted Featured Offer program, which gives products prime real estate on product pages. A Featured Offer, also known as the Buy Box, is prominently displayed at the top of an Amazon product page, alongside the “Add to Cart” and “Buy Now” buttons, making it easier for customers to purchase the featured item rather than the same product sold by other merchants.Recently, Amazon launched Haul, an app section that sells goods priced under $20 aimed to take on competition from the likes of Temu and Shein.Previously, Amazon excluded Temu from its price comparison system, potentially due to concerns about counterfeit products on the platform. However, with Temu's growing success, Amazon seems to be changing tactics.This situation puts Chinese sellers in a difficult position. They need to balance lower prices on Temu's platform, favored by the algorithm, with maintaining good standing on Amazon, crucial for reaching a wider audience. Some sellers are resorting to changing product pictures on Temu to avoid detection by Amazon.An Amazon representative denied the report and said that “sellers decide their selling strategy and set their own product prices in the Amazon store, and Amazon does not ask them to set certain prices.”

The changes come after sanctions were imposed on Russia after its war with Ukraine hampered trade with China and Turkey.Citing Russia’s finance minister Anton Siluanov, news agency Reuters reported that the companies in the country have begun using digital currencies in foreign trade following recent legislative changes that legalised their use.Russia legalised the use of cryptocurrencies in foreign trade and has taken steps to regulate cryptocurrency mining. Russia is a major player in Bitcoin mining, and Siluanov highlighted that Bitcoin mined within Russia is already being used for international payments.“As part of the experimental regime, it is possible to use bitcoins, which we had mined here in Russia (in foreign trade transactions ),” Siluanov told Russia 24 television channel.“Such transactions are already occurring. We believe they should be expanded and developed further. I am confident this will happen next year,” he said, adding that international payments in digital currencies represent the future.Earlier this year, Siluanov urged the public to stay away from crypto investment.“Some people see cryptocurrency as a source of quick money. I don’t recommend it as a means of investment,” the minister statedEarlier this month, Russian President Vladimir Putin criticised the US for using the dollar as a political weapon, arguing that this has undermined its role as the global reserve currency and driven countries to seek alternative assets like Bitcoin.
Article Summary: Russia legalised the use of cryptocurrencies in foreign trade and has taken steps to regulate cryptocurrency mining. The changes come after sanctions were imposed on Russia after its war with Ukraine hampered trade with China and Turkey. Russia is a major player in Bitcoin mining, and Bitcoin mined within Russia is already being used for international payments.

Article Title: Japan Airlines says systems back to normal after cyberattack cripples ticket sales, flights
Article Text:
[Notice regarding network equipment malfunction as of 19:40]

There was a system malfunction with our network equipment today, but it has now been resolved.

As of now, flights for tomorrow, December 27th, are scheduled to operate as normal.

We apologize for any inconvenience caused.

No customer data leaked

Japan Airlines (JAL) has restored its systems and resumed ticket sales after a cyberattack disrupted domestic and international flights earlier on Thursday (December 26).The attack, which began at 7.24 am local time, affected both internal and external systems, prompting JAL to temporarily shut down a malfunctioning router and suspend ticket sales for flights departing on Thursday.JAL assured that no customer information was compromised and that the company suffered no damage from computer viruses. ANA Holdings, Japan's other major airline, reported no impact on its systems from the cyberattack.As per news agency Reuters, the disruption led to delays of more than 24 domestic flights, with delays exceeding 30 minutes each.While Japanese authorities investigated the incident, local media suggested that the disruption could be due to a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack, where networks are overwhelmed by concentrated data traffic from multiple sources.Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshimasa Hayashi directed the transport ministry to expedite system restoration efforts and ensure proper accommodation for affected passengers.Earlier in the day, television footage showed crowds of stranded travelers at Tokyo's Haneda airport. The disruption coincided with the start of Japan's New Year holiday season, which is the country's peak travel period.This incident comes on the heels of a technical glitch that grounded all American Airlines flights for an hour on Christmas Eve, disrupting travel for thousands of passengers.
Article Summary: Japan Airlines (JAL) has restored its systems and resumed ticket sales after a cyberattack disrupted domestic and international flights earlier on Thursday. The attack, which began at 7.24 am local time, affected both internal and external systems, prompting JAL to temporarily shut down a malfunctioning router and suspend ticket sales. JAL assured that no customer information was compromised and that the company suffered no damage from computer viruses.

However, it is seen as a potential step towards greater internet freedom within the country. Iran has a history of restricting access to social media platforms and other online services, citing security concerns."A positive majority vote has been reached to lift limitations on access to some popular foreign platforms such as WhatsApp and Google Play", Iran's official IRNA news agency said on Tuesday, referring to a meeting on the matter headed by President Masoud Pezeshkian."Today the first step in removing internet limitations... has been taken," IRNA cited Iran's Minister of Information and Communications Technology Sattar Hashemi as saying.The long-term implications of this decision are also uncertain. It's unclear whether the lifted bans are permanent or temporary. Additionally, it remains to be seen if the government will impose any restrictions on how these platforms can be used within the country.

Article Title: Japan Airlines Hit by Cyberattack: Cyberattack disrupts Japan Airlines flights, ticket sales suspended
Article Text:
Japan Airlines hit by cyberattack

Japan Airlines (JAL) experienced a significant cyberattack on Thursday morning, causing flight delays and suspended ticket sales during Japan's busiest holiday travel season.The attack, which began at 7:24 a.m. local time, affected both internal and external systems of Japan's flagship carrier, forcing the airline to temporarily shut down a router causing system malfunctions, according to JAL officials.Reuters reports that the disruption led to delays of more than 24 domestic flights, with delays exceeding 30 minutes each. The airline also suspended ticket sales for all flights scheduled to depart on Thursday.Japanese authorities are investigating the incident, with local media suggesting the possibility of a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack, where networks are overwhelmed by concentrated data traffic from multiple sources.Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshimasa Hayashi has directed the transport ministry to expedite system restoration efforts and ensure proper accommodation for affected passengers. Television footage showed crowds of stranded travelers at Tokyo's Haneda airport as the disruption coincided with the start of Japan's New Year holiday season, traditionally the country's peak travel period.The incident appears to be isolated to JAL, as other major Japanese carriers, including ANA Holdings, Skymark, and Starflyer, reported no similar issues with their systems.This cyber incident follows a similar disruption earlier this week when American Airlines briefly grounded all flights for an hour on Christmas Eve due to a technical glitch, though the events appear to be unrelated.JAL officials emphasized that while operations were affected, there was no impact on flight safety. The airline continues to work on resolving the system issues while accommodating affected passengers during this critical holiday period.
Article Summary: Japan Airlines (JAL) experienced a significant cyberattack on Thursday morning, causing flight delays and suspended ticket sales. The attack, which began at 7:24 a.m. local time, affected both internal and external systems, forcing the airline to temporarily shut down a router causing system malfunctions. The disruption coincided with the start of Japan's New Year holiday season.
